Box: 87, Helwan, 11421, Cairo, Egypt ⁎ Corresponding author. Photocatalysis offers an environmentally friendly method for driving oxidation and reduction reactions. This process begins when light excites a semiconductor, generating electron-hole pairs (e⁻–h⁺) that facilitate chemical transformations. Aniline serves as a fundamental building block in chemical engineering, playing a pivotal role in the synthesis of numerous industrial products. This study reports a facile polymer-assisted sol-gel synthesis of iron phosphate (FePO4) nanocrystals, followed by the incorporation of different amounts (4–16 wt. %) of silver vandates (AgVO3) via precipitation. Comprehensive physicochemical characterization revealed the formation of mesoporous structures and highlighted the profound influence of AgVO3 on the optical and electronic properties of FePO4. Notably, the addition of 12 wt. % AgVO3 reduced the bandgap energy from 3.24 eV to 2.6 eV, significantly enhancing visible-light absorption. The optimized 12 wt. % AgVO3-FePO4 catalyst (2.0 g/L) achieved complete conversion of nitrobenzene to industrially valuable aniline within 45 min. under visible light while exhibiting excellent recyclability. The AgVO3 loading markedly improved charge carrier separation and mobility, as confirmed by photoelectrochemical analyses. This work paves the way for further exploration of phosphate-based heterostructures in the sustainable production of high-value industrial chemicals, demonstrating their potential for efficient and selective photocatalytic transformations. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords AgVO3 FePO4 Photocatalysis Nitrobenzene Aniline Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Nitrobenzene (NB) is a hazardous organic material that may exist in industrial wastewater, dyes, pesticides, food, medications, and soil. NB is toxic, highly stable, and bioaccumulated in groundwater water, causing immediate and long-term toxicity and severe health problems, such as mutagenicity and carcinogenesis; so, it is listed in the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) list as one of the important environmental pollutants [1]. The harmful effect of NB on human health and the environment was faced by chemical conversion to aniline (AN) through photocatalytic reduction, where AN is a less toxic species [1,2]. AN was applied in different fields, including the pharmaceutics industry, drug delivery and anticancer, supplementary materials of nutrition and food additives, dyes and colored pigments, sensors and biosensors, polymers, corrosion resistance, agrochemicals, supercapacitors and batteries [3–7]. In recent years, photocatalysis has established itself as a key method in organic synthesis, facilitating the formation of complex compounds under mild, light-driven conditions [8–16]. The photocatalytic reduction of NB to AN using homogenous metal-based catalysts was reported extensively [17,18]; though, this type of catalysis in the conversion of NB to AN suffers many weaknesses, such as environment contamination by harsh and hazardous species, high cost and difficulty of recyclability, security, and low safety (elevated pressure and temperature), and low selectivity [17,18]. The photoreduction using heterogeneous semiconductor catalysts was the solution for these drawbacks, which is due to sustainability, ease of operation, efficiency, selectivity, green method and cost-effectiveness for hydrogen production, eco-friendly and safe method, and promising alternative for the metal-based catalysts [18–21]; however, these semiconductor photocatalysts displays two main limitations, the catalyst recovery and the large energy bandgap [19–21]. Accordingly, several reports were found for the preparation, modification, and optimization of the heterogenous catalyst using two or more semiconductors to improve the photocatalytic routine [18–20,22]. Metal phosphates were promising species for photocatalysis and were used for different environmental remediation purposes. FePO4, Zn3(PO4)2, BiPO4, and others were prepared independently or with varying semiconductors for the degradation, reduction, or elimination of the polluting species through photocatalysis for environmental remediation and sustainability purposes [23–25]. Zn3(PO4)2 platelets were synthesized, characterized, and applied for the photocatalytic degradation of rhodamine B [26]. However, its g-C3N4/Zn3(PO4)2 composite was synthesized and applied for the removal of the crystal violet dye under visible light illumination [27]. Also, Ag3PO4 and its Ag3PO4/ g-C3N4 were applied as photocatalysts for the degradation of rhodamine B and methyl orange/tetracycline, respectively [28,29]. Another type is bismuth phosphate, BiPO4; its polymorph structure was used for the photodegradation of rhodamine B using UV irradiation [23]. Other BiPO4 nanostructures with different morphologies were prepared using microwave, rod-like, needle-like, and rice-like structures [25]; the photocatalysis of these morphologies was studied, and they exhibited photocatalytic ability for the degradation of organic dyes using UV and visible light illumination [25]. With respect to heterostructures, BiPO4/Bi2MoO6 was synthesized in one step using a solvothermal method and applied as an effective photocatalyst for the degradation of methylene blue dye using Z-scheme [24]. Another bismuth heterojunction photocatalyst is Bi2CuO4/BiPO4, which was applied for the degradation of important organic pollutants such as picric acid and methylene blue dye [30]. Other heterostructures of BiPO4 were prepared and applied in photocatalysis applications, Eu3+ and Sm3+ co-doped BiPO4 [31]. One of the important n-type photocatalyst semiconductors is iron phosphate (FePO4). It is characterized by its biocompatibility, good optical properties, photocatalysis ability, and reliable conductivity [32–34]. It was applied for the photocatalytic removal of dye and pharmaceutical-polluting species, such as ibuprofen [32] and methyl violet 2B [34], under visible illumination. However, the wide band gap (Eg) of 3.05 eV limits the application of this semiconductor as a photocatalyst. Consequently, FePO4 was mixed with different species for the preparation of heterogeneous catalysts that exhibited a lower band gap and, thus, higher photocatalytic activity. FePO4 was mixed with polyaniline, and the resulting nanocomposite was applied to photodegradate methyl orange using visible light [33]. The photocatalytic degradation of methylene blue was also performed using graphene oxide-FePO4 nanocomposite as a Fenton-like catalyst [35]. Also, the CuI/FePO4 heterogenous nanocomposite was prepared, characterized, and applied as a p-n heterojunction photocatalyst for amoxicillin degradation [36]. Generally, the FePO4 photocatalyst and its nanocomposite are stable, eco-friendly, and recyclable. Metal vanadates were applied in different industrial and scientific purposes, which is due to their small band gap energy, which facilitated their use in photocatalysis [37–40]. Different metal vanadates and their heterostructure nanocomposites were applied as photocatalysts, such as InVO4/AgVO3 [40], BiVO4/FeVO4 [39], Ag/InVO4-TiO2 thin films [37], and silver vanadates (α-AgVO3, β-AgVO3, Ag4V2O7, and Ag3VO4) [38]. AgVO3, silver vanadate, is an n-type semiconductor that exhibits a small bandgap energy of ∼ 2.5 eV [38]. AgVO3 is characterized by its excellent chemical, photoelectric, and physical properties, which results in the different applications of AgVO3, including the development of novel electronic devices and catalysts, antibacterial agents for industry and biomedical applications, degradation of industrial waste, environmental remediation, water splitting (H2 evolution), N2 fixation, and CO2 reduction [37,38,40–42]. The photocatalytic performance of AgVO3 was optimized by different methods, including loading of metal nanoparticles for surface modification, heterojunction engineering, and defect engineering [43–47], which resulted in charge recombination mitigation and improvement of visible light absorption, which caused improved catalysis properties [42,48,49]. Fabrication of AgVO3-based heterostructure photocatalyst is an effective way to enhance photocatalytic properties, and it was applied to industrial, environmental, and antibacterial applications [40,42,48–51]. For example, InVO4/AgVO3 heterojunctions were prepared for the enhanced photocatalytic antifouling [40]; rGO/AgVO3 nanocomposite was prepared and used for the degradation of Rhodamine B and Methylene blue under solar light irradiation [50]. Also, the Ag/AgVO3/WO3 catalyst was applied for the photocatalytic degradation of antibiotics [51]. In this work, a mesoporous AgVO3-FePO4 heterojunction photocatalyst was prepared and applied successfully for effective environmental remediation through photocatalytic reduction of carcinogenic nitrobenzene to aniline under visible illumination. The nanocomposite photocatalyst showed synergetic effects of energy gap reduction and effective photoinduced charge carriers (electron-hole pairs) separation, which increased the ability of light-harvesting and increased photocatalysis behavior. 2 Experimental part 2.1 Synthesis of FePO4 A solution was generated by mixing 1.6 g of Pluronic l-64 in 60 mL of ethanol (C2H5OH). To this, 1.62 g of Fe(NO3)3·9H2O, 1.43 g of Na2HPO4·12H2O, 1.48 mL of HCl, 40 mL of distilled water, and 4.6 mL of acetic acid (CH3COOH) were added. The mixture was stirred vigorously for 1 hour. The resulting solution was then transferred into a Petri dish and allowed to get polymerized for 12 h at 40 °C (with a chamber moisture of about 40 %), and then it was dried for 24 h at 65 °C. Finally, the as-prepared material was calcined at 550 °C for 5 h to remove the l-64 surfactant and obtain the mesoporous FePO4 matrix. 2.2 Synthesis of AgVO3-FePO4 photocatalysts Mesoporous FePO4 was impregnated with AgVO3 nanoparticles (NPs) at varying loadings (4–16 wt %) through a calcination-assisted process. In a typical procedure, 1.0 g of mesoporous FePO4 was dispersed in 100 mL of ethanol under ultrasonication for 15 min. Subsequently, AgNO3 and NH4VO3 (in a 1:1 molar ratio of Ag: V) were introduced into the suspension, followed by agitation for 60 min. The mixture was then subjected to ethanol evaporation, and the resulting solid was dried at 110 °C overnight. Finally, the powder was calcined at 500 °C for 3 h to obtain mesoporous AgVO3-FePO4 nanocomposites with 4, 8, 12, and 16 wt % AgVO3 loading. Detailed structural (XRD, TEM), surface (BET, XPS), and optical analyses are available in the Supporting Information. 2.3 Photocatalytic reduction of nitrobenzene The photoreduction experiments were performed under visible-light irradiation using a 500 W xenon lamp equipped with a UV cut-off filter positioned at a fixed distance of 15 cm from the reactor. The reaction temperature was precisely controlled at 299 K (±1 K) using a water circulation system. A 10 mL aqueous solution of 0.813 mM NB, containing 1 vol % methanol as a sacrificial agent, served as the standard reaction mixture. The catalyst concentration was varied between 0.5–2.5 g/L. Before the illumination, the system underwent a 30-minute dark adsorption phase under continuous stirring to achieve adsorption-desorption equilibrium, followed by 30 min of nitrogen purging to eliminate dissolved oxygen. Upon initiating irradiation, the photocatalytic reaction commenced, and its progress was tracked through periodic sampling. Collected aliquots were immediately filtered (0.45 μm syringe filters) and analyzed via GC-FID (Agilent 7890A). The photoreduction efficiency (PE, %) was calculated using the following equation: (1) PE ( % ) = C 0 − C t C 0 × 100 where C0 and Ct represent the initial and time-dependent concentrations of NB, respectively. A model of pseudo-first order was used to assess the photocatalytic reduction kinetics: (2) Ln ( C t C o ) = − k . t where k is the reaction rate constant (min-1), calculated from the slope of the linear correlation of ln( Ct / C0 ) against irradiation duration. This kinetic analysis provides fundamental insight into the photocatalytic efficiency and reaction dynamics. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characterization of the produced photocatalysts Fig. 1 displays the XRD patterns of pristine FePO4 and AgVO3-FePO4 photocatalysts with varying AgVO3 loadings. All samples showed distinct diffraction peaks corresponding to the hexagonal structure of FePO4 (JCPDS-29–0715), at 2θ values indexed to the crystallographic 20.2° (100), 25.7° (012), 35.5° (111), 38.1° (110), 39.2° (104), 41.4° (112), 48.6° (114), 52.9° (016), 58.4° (212), and 65.7° (124) [52,53]. After AgVO3 incorporation, new peaks appeared at 2θ = 27.8°, 32.62°, 43.92°, and 50.92°, assigned to the (−211), (−411), (710), and (020) planes of the monoclinic phase of β-AgVO3 (JCPDS-029–1154) [54,55]. The sharp peaks indicate high crystallinity in both pure FePO4 and AgVO3-FePO4 composites. For the 4 wt % AgVO3-FePO4 sample, the lack of prominent AgVO3 peaks suggests the minimal doping and homogeneous distribution of AgVO3 within the FePO4 matrix. The reduction in FePO4 peak intensities upon Ag/V precursor addition may result from lattice strain or heterojunction formation [56]. However, no impurity phases were observed, confirming the phase-pure integration of FePO4 and AgVO3 without structural degradation. Using the Debye-Scherrer equation, the average crystallite size of pristine FePO4 was determined to be 60–100 nm, whereas the AgVO3-FePO4 photocatalyst (with 4–16 % AgVO3 loading) exhibited a smaller crystallite size of 25–70 nm. To investigate the chemical composition and surface properties of the 12wt % AgVO3-FePO4 composite, X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was conducted. As depicted in Fig. 2 a, the Fe2p spectrum was resolved into four distinct peaks at binding energies of 711.18, 719.78, 724.88, and 733.48 eV, corresponding to Fe2p3/2, its satellite peak, Fe2p1/2, and its satellite peak, respectively [57]. These findings confirm the presence of Fe(III) in FePO4 [52]. The P 2p spectra exhibit a prominent signal at 133.98 eV, consistent with the characteristic binding energy of PO4 –3, as shown in Fig. 2b [58]. High-resolution XPS analysis of the Ag3d core level (Fig. 2c) shows two primary spin-orbit doublets (Ag3d5/2 and Ag3d3/2), each deconvoluted into two peaks, indicating two distinct oxidation states of Ag. The Ag3d5/2 peak was fitted with two components at 368.58 eV (Ag0) and 367.88 eV (Ag+) [51,59]. Similarly, the Ag3d₃/₂ peak exhibited corresponding signals at binding energies of 375.08 eV (Ag0) and 373.88 eV (Ag+). The presence of Ag0 likely results from the partial thermal decomposition of silver oxide or the reduction of excess silver nitrate during the synthesis process [60,61]. The XPS spectrum in Fig. 2d displays characteristic vanadium peaks at 516.88 eV (V2p3/2) and 524.48 eV (V2p1/2) with spin-orbit splitting of 7.6 eV, which are assigned to the V5+oxidation state [51]. The O1s spectrum was deconvoluted into two distinct peaks at 530.5 eV and 533.2 eV, assigned to lattice oxygen in the metal-oxide and adsorbed hydroxyl oxygen [62]. These XPS results are consistent with the XRD data, confirming the successful synthesis of the AgVO3-FePO4 composite. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) was employed to investigate the morphological and structural properties of pure FePO4 and different AgVO3-FePO4 composites. As shown in Fig. 3 a, the pristine FePO4 sample consists of irregularly shaped nanoparticles with significant agglomeration, exhibiting particle sizes between 50 and 200 nm. The synthesized submicron rods exhibit random orientation and interconnected morphology, a characteristic outcome of the self-assembly process mediated by the Pluronic l-64 structure-directing agent [63,64]. The AgVO3-FePO4 composites (Fig. 3b-3e) retain the original structural framework of FePO4 while incorporating well-dispersed AgVO3 nanoparticles. This configuration facilitates the formation of extensive heterojunction interfaces without disrupting the host matrix. By increasing the Ag+ and V2+ precursor content from 4.0 wt % to 16.0 wt %, we observed a corresponding increase in nanoparticle density. HR-TEM imaging (Fig. 3f) confirms the composite’s dual-phase nature, displaying distinct lattice fringes with spacings of 0.34 nm (FePO4 (012) plane) and 0.13 nm (AgVO3 (−411) plane), matching standard references for hexagonal FePO4 and monoclinic AgVO3 [59,65]. The selected-area electron diffraction (SAED) pattern (inset, Fig. 3f) exhibits a hybrid ring structure, indicative of the material’s mesoporous and polycrystalline characteristics. These TEM findings align closely with XRD and XPS results, providing conclusive evidence for the successful synthesis of the AgVO3-FePO4 heterojunction. The photocatalytic evolution performance was significantly dependent on specific surface area and pore structure characteristics. Nitrogen adsorption-desorption measurements (Fig. 4 ) revealed type IV isotherms with distinct hysteresis loops for all samples in the relative pressure range (P/P0 = 0.42–0.96), indicative of a hierarchical porous structure combining microporous and mesoporous domains with cylindrical pore geometry, confirming their mesoporous nature [66,67]. Pore size distribution analysis indicated diameters ranging from 1 to 65 nm (Fig. S1). Notably, AgVO3 incorporation had a negligible impact on the composite's mesoporous architecture. The quantitative analysis yielded an average pore diameter of 8.23 nm for both FePO4 and AgVO3-FePO4 composites, confirming their mesoporous character, a particularly advantageous feature for aqueous pollutant adsorption applications. BET surface area measurements demonstrated a gradual decrease from 135 m2/g (pristine FePO4) to 119 m2/g (16 wt % AgVO3-FePO4), following the series: 135 (FePO4) > 131 (4 wt % AgVO3) > 128 (8 wt % AgVO3) > 124 (12 wt % AgVO3) > 119 m²/g (16 wt % AgVO3). This systematic reduction suggests progressive pore occupation by AgVO3 nanoparticles. Importantly, despite this surface area variation, the fundamental textural characteristics of the composites remained largely unaltered, maintaining structural similarity to the parent FePO4 material. 3.2 Optical properties The optical properties of pristine FePO4 and AgVO3-FePO4 composites were analazed by UV–vis diffuse reflectance spectroscopy with corresponding Tauc plot analysis. As shown in Fig. 5 , pristine FePO4 exhibited an absorption edge at 405.5 nm, indicating limited utilization of visible light. In contrast, AgVO3 demonstrated significantly enhanced visible-light absorption. The incorporation of AgVO3 nanoparticles onto FePO4 nanocrystals resulted in a distinct red-shift of the absorption edge for the AgVO3-FePO4 composites with increasing AgVO3 content, suggesting bandgap narrowing (Table 1 ) and the successful establishment of a heterojunction structure [68,69]. Bandgap energies (Eg) derived from Tauc plots (inset of Fig. 5) revealing a systematic reduction in bandgap with increasing AgVO3 loading: 3.24 eV (pristine FePO4) > 2.75 eV (4 wt % AgVO3) > 2.78 eV (8 wt % AgVO3) > 2.66 eV (16 wt % AgVO3) > 2.60 eV (12 wt % AgVO3), in good agreement with reported values [51,70]. This progressive narrowing of the bandgap suggests effective electronic interaction between FePO4 and AgVO3 phases, potentially enhancing visible-light absorption capabilities and indicating improved photoresponse characteristics, thereby boosting photocatalytic performance. Photoluminescence (PL) spectroscopy was employed to probe the charge carrier recombination dynamics in the photocatalysts (Fig. 6 a) [71]. The PL spectrum of pristine FePO4 displayed a strong emission peak centered at 463 nm, revealing inefficient charge separation due to rapid electron-hole recombination. The 12wt % AgVO3-FePO4 composite exhibited significantly quenched PL intensity compared to both pure FePO4 and other composites, indicating markedly suppressed electron-hole recombination. This observed PL quenching demonstrates more efficient charge separation in the 12wt % AgVO3-FePO4 heterostructure, which is crucial for enhancing photocatalytic activity. This originates from two synergistic effects induced by AgVO3 incorporation: (1) its narrow bandgap introduces oxygen vacancy states that create intermediate energy levels within the ZWO band structure, and (2) these defect states function as effective electron-transfer mediators [72–74]. The reduced recombination probability of photogenerated charge carriers in 12wt % AgVO3-FePO4 suggests improved charge transfer at the heterojunction interface, consistent with its superior photocatalytic performance. Additionally, the charge separation efficiency of the photocatalysts was evaluated through transient photocurrent measurements under multiple on-off cycles. Photocurrent measurements serve as a reliable indicator of photocatalytic efficiency, as enhanced charge separation typically correlates with superior degradation performance. Fig. 6b presents the comparative transient photocurrent responses of pristine FePO4 and AgVO3-FePO4 composites under pulsed illumination. The 12 wt % AgVO3-FePO4 composite exhibited the highest photocurrent density (∼13.8 µA/cm2) among all tested materials (Table 1), demonstrating approximately 5.75 times greater response than pristine FePO4 (∼2.4 µA/cm2). This enhanced photocurrent response indicates more efficient separation of photogenerated electron-hole pairs, reduced charge carrier recombination, and improved electrical conductivity within the composite. The superior photocurrent performance of 12 wt % AgVO3-FePO4 correlates well with its exceptional photocatalytic activity, confirming that the heterojunction structure effectively promotes charge separation and transport [57,75,76]. 3.3 Photocatalytic activity evaluation To evaluate the photocatalytic performance of pure FePO4 and AgVO3-FePO4 composites, nitrobenzene (NB) was selected as a model organic pollutant in an aqueous solution. The reduction of NB to aniline (AN) was tracked under simulated solar light at ambient conditions. Control experiments, performed in darkness and without photocatalysts to assess NB photolysis, were carried out under the same conditions. The influence of AgVO3 loading on the photocatalytic efficiency of AgVO3-FePO4 nanocomposites was also examined. As shown in Fig. 7 a, the catalytic activity of the synthesized photocatalysts was tested via solar-light-driven NB conversion. NB is highly stable, showing only 2 % degradation via photolysis after one hour. However, the introduction of catalysts significantly enhanced conversion efficiency. With 12 wt % AgVO3-FePO4, complete NB conversion (100 %) was achieved within one hour, far exceeding the performance of pure FePO4 (3 %). This improvement is attributed to AgVO3’s dual function in boosting light absorption and facilitating p-n junction formation. The incorporation of AgVO3 can significantly improve visible light utilization. However, due to its limited reduction capability, excessive loading should be avoided. When the amount of AgVO3 is too high (16 wt %), a light-shielding effect and disrupted electron transfer at the AgVO3-FePO4 interface occurs due to nanoparticle agglomeration on FePO4 nanocrystal surfaces as observed in Fig. 3e, leading to reducing the generation of active radicals and ultimately lowering photocatalytic activity [55]. The NB reduction kinetics followed a pseudo-first-order model (Fig. 7b), with the calculated rate constants ( k ) listed in Table 1. The 12 wt % AgVO3-FePO4 composite exhibited the highest performance, with a rate constant of 5.2 × 10–2 min-1, which is 130 times greater than that of pure FePO4 (0.04 × 10–2 min-1). This underscores the substantial catalytic enhancement achieved through optimal AgVO3 incorporation. The influence of photocatalyst dosage (0.5–2.5 g/L) on NB reduction efficiency was investigated using the optimized 12 wt % AgVO3-FePO4 composite. As shown in Fig. 8 a, increasing the catalyst concentration from 0.5 g/L to 2.0 g/L enhanced the NB conversion rate from 60 % to 100 % within 45 min of visible-light irradiation. This improvement is attributed to the increased generation of OH radicals at optimal catalyst loading. However, beyond 2.0 g/L, excessive turbidity hindered light penetration due to intensified scattering effects [67], reducing the conversion efficiency to 88 % at 2.5 g/L. Kinetic analysis (Fig. 8b) followed a pseudo-first-order model, revealing a ∼6-fold increase in the rate constant (7.49 × 10–2 min-1) at 2.0 g/L compared to 0.5 g/L (see inset table). This confirms that higher catalyst loading (up to 2.0 g/L) improves the density of active sites, facilitating more efficient NB adsorption and reduction. Moreover, the 12 wt % AgVO3-FePO4 photocatalyst exhibited excellent stability, retaining ∼96 % of its initial activity after five cycles (Fig. 8c). As seen in Fig. S2, TEM analysis confirmed that the material maintained its morphological stability even after the fifth reuse cycle. Additionally, inductive coupling plasma spectroscopy revealed no detectable leaching of Ag, V, or Fe ions into the reaction solution. The slight decline in catalytic performance is attributed to partial catalyst loss and nanoparticle aggregation, which reduces catalytic active site availability and surface area [77,78]. A comparison with recent studies on NB photoreduction (Table S1) highlights that the optimized AgVO3-FePO4 composite exhibits superior efficiency among reported photocatalysts. These results demonstrate the composite’s robustness for practical applications under visible light. 3.4 Potential photocatalytic mechanism The incorporation of AgVO3 into FePO4 creates a stable n-n heterojunction, which enhances visible-light absorption and promotes the separation of photoinduced charges. The proposed photocatalytic mechanism, involving charge transfer for NB reduction, is illustrated in Fig. 9 . Firstly, radical trapping experiments were conducted to identify the key reactive species involved in the photoreduction of NB using the AgVO3-FePO4 nanocomposite (Fig. S3). In the absence of a scavenger, a complete reduction of NB was achieved. When isopropanol (IPA) and EDTA disodium dihydrate were introduced, the reduction efficiency was only slightly reduced (98 % and 94 %, respectively), suggesting that holes (h +) and hydroxyl radicals (•OH) play a minor role. However, adding benzoquinone (a superoxide radical quencher) caused a sharp decline in efficiency (22 %), demonstrating that superoxide radicals (•O2⁻) are the dominant species responsible for NB reduction over the AgVO3-FePO4 photocatalyst. The conduction (CB) and valence band (VB) positions of AgVO3 and FePO4 were determined using Mott-Schottky plots (Fig. S4, supplementary materials). The negative slopes confirm their n-type semiconductor nature [79,80]. The flat band potentials (EFB) for AgVO3 and FePO4 were measured at +0.42 V and +0.366 V (vs. SCE). For n-type semiconductors, the CB is typically ∼0.1 V higher than EFB [81,82]. Thus, the CB levels of AgVO3 and FePO4 are: +0.32 V (vs. SCE) / +0.564 V (vs. NHE) for AgVO3 and +0.266 V (vs. SCE) / +0.51 V (vs. NHE) for FePO4. Consequently, their VB potentials are +2.664 V (vs. NHE) for AgVO3 and +3.97 V (vs. NHE) for FePO4. Under visible light, the n-n heterojunction generates an interfacial electric field, following the S-scheme mechanism [56,83–86]. Due to band bending, AgVO3’s CB and VB shift to more negative energies, while FePO4’s CB and VB shift to more positive energies. This facilitates the recombination of e⁻s from FePO4’s CB (less negative) with h⁺s in AgVO3’s VB (less positive). The remaining e⁻ in AgVO3’s CB and h⁺ in FePO4’s VB, which drives the NB photoreduction. The reduction pathway in which NB is reduced to AN via a six-electron, six-proton coupled transfer mechanism, as outlined in Eq. (3). Meanwhile, the oxidation pathway involves the oxidation of methanol to formaldehyde via the remaining holes, releasing protons in the process, as described in Eq. (4): (3) C 6 H 5 N O 2 a d s . + A g V O 3 ( 6 e − C B ) + 6 H + → C 6 H 5 N H 2 a d s . + 2 H 2 O (4) 2 C h 3 O H a d s . + F e P O 4 ( 6 h + V B ) → 6 H + + 3 H C H O Finally, the synthesized AgVO3-FePO4 nanocomposites exhibit remarkable efficiency in wastewater treatment, enabling the high-yield reduction of aromatic pollutants into value-added products under visible-light irradiation. This study presents a practical and sustainable photocatalytic system that effectively combines environmental remediation with the synthesis of useful chemical products. 4 Conclusions This work demonstrates a surfactant-assisted sol-gel approach followed by impregnation for fabricating AgVO3-FePO4 nanocomposites. The resulting n-n heterojunction exhibits a mesoporous architecture with significantly increased visible-light capture, enhanced charge flexibility, and outstanding photocatalytic ability for the photoreduction of nitrobenzene into aniline. These improvements stem from the synergistic effects of incorporating narrow bandgap AgVO3, which extends light absorption to ∼540.3 nm and decreases the bandgap to ∼2.6 eV in the optimal 12wt % AgVO3-FePO4 composite. Under visible-light irradiation, the 12 wt % AgVO3-FePO4 photocatalyst (2.0 g/L) achieves an outstanding nitrobenzene reduction rate of 7.49 × 10–2 min-1 within 45 min, while maintaining 96 % activity over five consecutive cycles, demonstrating remarkable stability. Fermi-level equilibration drives electron migration from FePO4 to AgVO3, creating an internal electric field (IEF) that enhances charge separation. The observed 80 % decrease in photoluminescence intensity combined with a 5.75-fold enhancement in photocurrent generation (compared to pure FePO4) provides clear evidence of superior charge separation. This improvement stems from the effective S-scheme charge transfer pathway that dramatically minimizes recombination losses. This study establishes a foundation for developing stable, phosphate-based photocatalytic systems suitable for sustainable chemical manufacturing processes. coredata.dc:description: Photocatalysis offers an environmentally friendly method for driving oxidation and reduction reactions. This process begins when light excites a semiconductor, generating electron-hole pairs (e⁻–h⁺) that facilitate chemical transformations. Aniline serves as a fundamental building block in chemical engineering, playing a pivotal role in the synthesis of numerous industrial products. This study reports a facile polymer-assisted sol-gel synthesis of iron phosphate (FePO4) nanocrystals, followed by the incorporation of different amounts (4–16 wt. %) of silver vandates (AgVO3) via precipitation. Comprehensive physicochemical characterization revealed the formation of mesoporous structures and highlighted the profound influence of AgVO3 on the optical and electronic properties of FePO4. Notably, the addition of 12 wt. % AgVO3 reduced the bandgap energy from 3.24 eV to 2.6 eV, significantly enhancing visible-light absorption. The optimized 12 wt. % AgVO3-FePO4 catalyst (2.0 g/L) achieved complete conversion of nitrobenzene to industrially valuable aniline within 45 min. under visible light while exhibiting excellent recyclability. The AgVO3 loading markedly improved charge carrier separation and mobility, as confirmed by photoelectrochemical analyses. This work paves the way for further exploration of phosphate-based heterostructures in the sustainable production of high-value industrial chemicals, demonstrating their potential for efficient and selective photocatalytic transformations.

coredata.dc:title: Simple preparation of AgVO3-modified iron phosphate nanostructures for improved photocatalytic reduction of nitrobenzene
